duck: Semivowel - In phonetics and phonology, a semivowel is a sound, such as English or that is phonetically similar to a vowel sound but functions as the syllable boundary rather than as the nucleus of a syllable.
Approximants are speech sounds that involve the articulators approaching each other but not narrowly enough or with enough articulatory precision to create turbulent airflow.

wiki.text:
'Approximants' are speech sounds that involve the articulators approaching each
other but not narrowly enough<ref></ref> nor with enough articulatory
precision<ref>, citing </ref> to create turbulent airflow. Therefore,
approximants fall between fricatives, which do produce a turbulent airstream,
and vowels, which produce no turbulence.<ref name="Martínez-Celdrán 2004
201"></ref> This class of sounds includes lateral approximants like (as in
less), non-lateral approximants like (as in rest), and semivowels like and (as
in yes and west, respectively).<ref name="Martínez-Celdrán 2004 201"/>

Before Peter Ladefoged coined the term "approximant" in the 1960s<ref>, pointing
to </ref> the term "frictionless continuant" referred to non-lateral
approximants.
wiki.title: Approximant%20consonant
